Posts.Content: Sivad, I don't know about the burning, but I had lots of itching in my younger years. I use to wear padded bras, and I found out that I was very allergic to some of the material they padded the bras with. I often could not wait until I got home from work to tear off that bra. It never itched the first thing in the morning, but it got bad later in the day. I finally realized I had an allergy to the paddings, and out they went. Even though I don't wear padded bras anymore, I still get itchy some time. It is that rubber material band which is on the inside on the bottom of the bra, I still get allergic to that, sometime when I come home and take the bra off, I have like a red itchy streak on the bottom of my bobs (sp-english is not my native language). So, you may have the same problem . Laura
Posts.Title: Suspicious Finding

Posts.Content: Sivad, of course you should go for a follow up, especially since the requested it with registered mail. They wanted to make sure you get the letter!! I also have a mammogram every year, this time I had to go for a follow up mammogram on the left side plus an ultrasound. There also was some suspicious shadow etc. A biopsy came out positive, breast cancer. I'm a senior and have annual mammograms for the last 30 years, once in a great while I had to go back for a follow up and it always turned out to be nothing. But this year...... So don't delay, go for your follow up. Laura
Posts.Title: Suspicious Finding

Posts.Content: Now and then I read on this board that patients have to go on arimidex/tamoifen etc. for as long as five years. I also read about the side effects. I just finished my last chemo and my oncologist said that I'm "Hormone Receptor Negative" and don't have to take any pills. That made me very happy. On the other hand, I'm wondering what it all means, I forgot to ask her. Is it a good sign when you don't have to take these pills? I had a lumpectomy, lymphnodes involved. Laura
Posts.Title: 5 year pill therapy

Posts.Content: I had an ultrasound guided biopsy and a MRI guided biopsy. Both did not hurt at all , my breast was numb. Laura
Posts.Title: Core biopsy with ultrsound

Posts.Content: I must say I never heard of anyone taking this medication without having cancer. You always learn. I know lots of people have to take tamoxifen after a breast cancer operation to prevent cancer to recur. I had a lumpectomy, followed by chemo therapy and radiation therapy. My oncologist told me I could not take tamoxifen because I am estrogen receptor negative and therefore the medication would not do any good for me. Laura
Posts.Title: To take Tamoxifen...that's the question!

Posts.Content: kam61, I think your post answered my question why I had a 2nd lumpectomy. Right after the first surgery my surgeon talked about margins and micro-scan and some other confusing words. If he had said that margins were not clean I probably would have understood better. With other words, they did not get everything the first time. The age of iturner's mom is also important, it is a known fact the cancer cells grow and divide so much slower in older people. Laura
Posts.Title: Delaying radiation?

Posts.Content: I read on this board, more than once, that radiation should start within four months of the operation. I started my 6 weeks radiation exactly 2 days ago, that is 8 months after my lumpectomy. My first lumpectomy was January 30, 2008 and then they had to do a second one February 19, 2008. Surgeon explained why 2 lumpectomies, but frankly, I still don't understand why. I also had cancer in the lymphnodes. I also had 2 mammograms, ultrasound, pet scan, muga scan etc. Seems weeks went by just testing. Then I had to go through chemotherapy, 8 treatments between March 17 and August 12, 2008. I'm also concerned that my radiation was delayed like that, but with all the tests and chemo, what could I do? I actually whished I could hear from other people if they also had such a long delay with their radiation. I personnally don't think the delay with you mother is that serious since it is in the 4 months span, especially since her lymphnodes were clean and she just had a lumpectomy. I'm sure if you talk with her oncologist he or she will agree. I was told that I'm cancerfree and all these procedures are necessaary just in case. Laura
Posts.Title: Delaying radiation?

Posts.Content: Thank you for your reply. I'm so sorry about your son. Your answer does help, I guess when I child can take that many, the scans are maybe not that harmful.
Posts.Title: PET Scan Question

Posts.Content: Don't worry about the biopsy yet, this is the only way for them to find out if there is cancer. I am elderly and have had many biopsies in my lifetime, they always came out negative, until now. What is so great about a biopsy that they find cancer early, if there is cancer.
Posts.Title: Mammogram, Ultrasound and now Biopsy

Posts.Content: Don't worry about the biopsy yet, this is the only way for them to find out if there is cancer. I am elderly and have had many biopsies in my lifetime, they always came out negative, until now. What is so great about a biopsy that they find cancer early, if there is cancer.
Posts.Title: Mammogram, Ultrasound and now Biopsy

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with breast cancer almost 5 years ago and had a lumpectomy (sp?) on my left breast. Every 6 month I go for a mammogram and gratefully, no cancer. My oncologist also sends me for a Pet Scan every six month. I had a total of 6 PET Scans since my lumpectomy and they also come out okay. My question is: Is it really necessary to have that many PET Scans? One every 6 months? Last time I refused the PET Scan and this coming January will be 12 months since my last PET Scan and I'm sure the oncologist will be after me to have again a PET Scan in January. Is it customary to have PET Scans with Mammograms that often?
Posts.Title: PET Scan Question

Posts.Content: You right, *******, that is 6 years ago. I'm going through chemo right now even though they said "they got it all." Oncologist said it is better to take some treatment, just in case, than trying to chase after cancer 2 - 3 years later. I have to take 8 treatments of chemo and then radiation. No fun, but without the treatments I would go through life wondering if the cancer shows up again? Laura
Posts.Title: I declined chemo & had my ovaries out instead

Posts.Content: Before I started my radiation therapy, they put 4 small tattoos around my breast. They told me that it was necessary to guide them where to direct the radiation. They also told me the tattoos would be permanently. I don't know how big your spot is, mine are only the size of a pencil point. I don't mind them, my health is more important to me. Laura
Posts.Title: Anyone Else Get "Tattooed" from Core Biopsy?

Posts.Content: I wonder about that 4 months window for radiation? I had two lumpectomies (they had to go back in 2 weeks after the first) The second lumpectomy was on 2/18/08. I have to have 8 chemotherapies, the first one was on 3/17/08. And I was told after I'm done with the chemo I have to have radiation treatments. That should be around August/September, that would be about a 5 to 6 month window? Laura
Posts.Title: when does radiation start after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hello, does anyone else has a severe rash problem? Kam 61, thank you for your reply, can't find that cream here in Florida.
Posts.Title: Rash from radiation

Posts.Content: Shisslak, the nurse was not harsh or curt, she was right. It's about a week since she told me it would get worse and the rash is getting worse. The radiation oncologist sees me once a week, he told me to try 1% cortisone cream. In fact, today they called someone in to look at my rash and that doctor said it is okay. I can't complain, everyone is extremely nice, never have to wait more than 5 minutes for my treatment. Today was the first time I really complained about how uncomfortable I am with that rash and they right away called that extra person to look at the rash, I guess she is a dermatologist. The rash is definite from the radiation, I was just wondering if other people's skin is as sensitive as mine. I'm very uncomfortable, as soon a I come home I take of my top, put my cream on and run around topless in the house. Even with just a T-shirt on, I feel very uncomfortable. Laura
Posts.Title: Rash from radiation

Posts.Content: Shisslak, you did not upset me. Before I came to Florida, I also lived in Massachusetts. I had a doctor in Cambride, MA, Harvard graduate, he was not that special! My radiology oncologist saw me yesterday (Friday) For the next 5 days, starting yesterday, they will not radiate the whole area, just direct radiation to one spot, where the tumor was. He said to give me a little relief. So you see, they care about me :bouncin I'm surprised that no one else complains about having a bad rash, am I the only one? Laura
Posts.Title: Rash from radiation

Posts.Content: I got 22 radiation therapies behind me with 11 more to go. About 2 weeks ago I started to develop a rash on the left breast, along my left collar bone and also a large area on the back of the left shoulder blade. I feel very uncomfortable because the rash is very itchy. They gave me a "Udder Cream" but it really does not help, in fact, when I use it it's more uncomfortable, because it feels like something is crawling on my skin. Whenever I come for my treatment they ask me if I have any pains, which I have not, but I tell them that the itch is driving me crazy. But they don't seem concerned, in fact, once the nurse said it will be getting worse. I read this board a lot but I never seen anyone talking about a rash during radiation. Is my skin especially sensitive? Laura
Posts.Title: Rash from radiation
